title: Researchers use superheated steam to sanitize dry food manufacturing plants - Food Safety News
summary: Researchers at Cornell University are developing a new sanitation tool using superheated dry steam to eliminate pathogens in dry food processing plants, a significant advancement for food safety. This innovation is particularly relevant for the milk powder and powdered infant formula industry, which has faced serious contamination issues. The research aims to establish best practices that reduce the need for water and sanitizers, aligning with sustainability goals. Funded by a $400,000 grant from the Center for Produce Safety, the project highlights the importance of maintaining safe processing environments for dry foods.
green_innovation: TRUE: This innovation reduces the demand on water and sanitizers in food manufacturing, aligning with sustainability goals and minimizing environmental impacts during food processing.
business_innovation: TRUE: The development of a new sanitation method with superheated steam qualifies as a business innovation as it significantly differs from conventional cleaning processes in food manufacturing.
